maml:description.maml:para: Formats one or more existing volumes or a new volume on an existing partition.

The Format-Volume cmdlet formats one or more existing volumes, or a new volume on an existing partition. This cmdlet returns the object representing the volume that was just formatted, with all properties updated to reflect the format operation.
To create a new volume, use this cmdlet in conjunction with the Initialize-Disk and New-Partition cmdlets.
Specifies the drive letter of the volume to format.
Specifies the allocation unit size to use when formatting the volume.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Enables compression on all files and folders created on the specified NTFS volume.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Indicates that the cmdlet does not gather file activity on the specified tiered volume. You can override file placement based on the desired storage tier. This parameter is only valid for tiered volumes.
Specifies the file system with which to format the volume. The acceptable values for this parameter are:NTFS, ReFS, exFAT, FAT32, and FAT.
Specifies the override switch.
Performs a full format. A full format writes to every sector of the disk, takes much longer to perform than the default (quick) format, and is not recommended on storage that is thinly provisioned.
Formats a volume as a DirectAccess (DAX) volume.
DAX provides applications with direct access and byte-addressability options via memory mapping on storage class memory (SCM) devices, such as NVDIMM-N.
If you do not specify the IsDAX parameter, the cmdlet defaults to a regular, non-DAX volume.
Specifies a new label to use for the volume.
Enables integrity streams on the volume to be formatted.
Specifies that support for short file names should be enabled on this volume.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies that large File Record Segment (FRS) should be used.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: Be careful, if using this cmdlet on a Windows Cluster, it would format all drives returned by the Get-Volume * cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example performs a format of the D volume.
This example performs a full format of the D volume using the FAT32 file system.

command:example.maml:title: ------- Example 3: Format all D drives across a cluster -------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Volume -DriveLetter D
DriveLetter FileSystemLabel FileSystem DriveType HealthStatus OperationalStatus SizeRemaining Size ----------- --------------- ---------- --------- ------------ ----------------- ------------- ---- D Server1 NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 126.76 GB 126.87 GB D Server2 NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 126.76 GB 126.87 GB
PS C:\> Format-Volume -DriveLetter D
DriveLetter FileSystemLabel FileSystem DriveType HealthStatus OperationalStatus SizeRemaining Size ----------- --------------- ---------- --------- ------------ ----------------- ------------- ---- D NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 126.76 GB 126.87 GB D NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 126.76 GB 126.87 GB

dev:remarks.maml:para: Be careful, if using this cmdlet on a Windows Cluster, it would format all drives returned by the Get-Volume cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -- Example 4: Full format using NTFS and allocation size 8192 --

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example performs a full format of the D volume using the NTFS file system and allocation size 8192.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the file system choices for a specified volume.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a count of the file system errors on the NTFS volume.

The Get-VolumeCorruptionCount cmdlet gets a count of the file system errors on the NTFS volume. Chkdsk scans a volume for file system errors and stores the result as metadata. This cmdlet enumerates the list of errors on the volume and returns a count of the errors. If you specify the Verbose parameter, the cmdlet also generates a description for each error.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the status of the volume scrub policy.
The Get-VolumeScrubPolicy cmdlet gets the status of the volume scrub policy.
Specifies an array of letters that identify one or more drives or volumes in the system. The cmdlet gets the volume scrub policy for the drives or volumes you specify.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: ------------ Example 1: Get the volume scrub policy ------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-Volume H | Set-VolumeScrubPolicy -Enable $False PS C:\> Get-VolumeScrubPolicy H

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the volume scrub policy to $False, and then gets the volume scrub policy to verify the change.

maml:description.maml:para: Optimizes a volume.

The Optimize-Volume cmdlet optimizes a volume, performing defragmentation, trim, slab consolidation, and storage tier processing. If no parameter is specified, then the default operation will be performed per the drive type as follows.
- HDD, Fixed VHD, Storage Space. -Analyze -Defrag.
- Tiered Storage Space. -TierOptimize.
- SSD with TRIM support. -Retrim.
- Storage Space (Thinly provisioned), SAN Virtual Disk (Thinly provisioned), Dynamic VHD, Differencing VHD. -Analyze -SlabConsolidate -Retrim.
- SSD without TRIM support, Removable FAT, Unknown. No operation.
Specifies the drive letter of the volume to optimize.
Analyzes the volume specified for fragmentation statistics. Performs analysis only and reports the current optimization state of the volume.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Indicates that the cmdlet initiates defragmentation on the specified volume. Defragmentation consolidates fragmented regions of files to improve performance of sequential reads or writes.
Indicates that this cmdlet the operation at normal priority. By default, the priority is low.

Generates TRIM and Unmap hints for all currently unused sectors of the volume, notifying the underlying storage that the sectors are no longer needed and can be purged. This can recover unused capacity on thinly provisioned drives.
Indicates that the cmdlet performs slab consolidation on the storage to optimize slab allocations and to reduce the number of used slabs.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Indicates that the cmdlet performs tier optimization of the volume, which places file data on the optimal storage tier according to heat or desired placement. This parameter only applies to tiered spaces volumes with more than one storage tier.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example optimizes drive H by re-sending Trim requests. This is useful on SSD media, and thinly provisioned storage.
This example reports only the current optimization state of drive H.
This example defragments drive H.
This example performs slab consolidation on the storage space backing volume H.
This example performs tier optimization on the tiered storage space backing volume H.

maml:description.maml:para: Performs repairs on a volume.
The Repair-Volume cmdlet performs repairs on a volume. The following repair actions are available:
OfflineScanAndFix: Takes the volume offline to scan the volume and fix any errors found (equivalent to `chkdsk /f`).
Scan: Scans the volume without attempting to repair it; all detected corruptions are added to the `$corrupt` system file (equivalent to `chkdsk /scan`).
SpotFix: Takes the volume briefly offline and then fixes only issues that are logged in the `$corrupt` file (equivalent to `chkdsk /spotfix`).
Specifies a letter used to identify a drive or volume in the system.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Performs and offline scan and fix of any errors found in the file system.
Scans the volume.
Takes the volume offline and fixes any issues that are logged in the $corrupt file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example scans the volume H: and reports errors only. It uses the `-DriveLetter` switch to designate the volume by its drive letter and `-Scan` to indicate the scanning action.

This example uses the spot verifier functionality to quickly fix volumes designation G:, H: and I:. It uses the `-DriveLetter` switch to designate multiple volumes by their drive letters and `SpotFix` to indicate the quick fixing action.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Volume
DriveLetter FriendlyName FileSystemType DriveType HealthStatus OperationalStatus SizeRemaining Size ----------- ------------ -------------- --------- ------------ ----------------- ------------- ---- System Reserved NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 178.47 MB 550 MB C Contoso - C NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 41.28 GB 98.89 GB NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 89.03 MB 481 MB FAT32 Fixed Healthy OK 70.8 MB 96 MB D Contoso - D NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 29.13 GB 67.68 GB E Contoso - E NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 148.44 GB 465.76 GB F Archives NTFS Fixed Healthy OK 324.13 GB 465.76 GB
PS C:\> Repair-Volume -FileSystemLabel "System Reserved" -OfflineScanAndFix

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example takes the System Reserved volume offline, and fixes all issues. This volume has no drive letters assigned to it. The first command, `Get-Volume` gives an overview of the volumes on the local computer. As the output indicates, the volume bearing the "System Reserved" label has no drive letters. Next, the `Repair-Volume` cmdlet uses the `-FileSystemLabel` switch to designate the "System Reserved" volume and the `-OfflineScanAndFix` switch indicates the volume should be taken offline and scanned in full.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the status of the volume scrub policy.
The Set-VolumeScrubPolicy cmdlet sets the status of the volume scrub policy. Use this cmdlet to enable or disable the policy.
Specifies an array of letters that identify one or more drives or volumes in the system. The cmdlet sets the volume scrub policy for the drives or volumes you specify.
Indicates whether to enable or disable the volume scrub policy.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a volume object, and then sets the volume scrub policy status on that object to $False.

maml:description.maml:para: Writes the file system cache to disk.
The Write-VolumeCache cmdlet writes the file system cache to disk. By default, Windows caches file data to be written to disk in a special memory area before writing the data to disk.
This cmdlet enables you to forcibly empty, or flush, the write cache by writing it to disk.
Specifies an array of letters that identify one or more drives or volumes in the system. The cmdlet writes the volume cache for the drives or volumes you specify.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.
